column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2

#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Summary1=(human1) An anonymous writer presents the example of the changes to the automotive industry, in particular the trend toward computerized cars, to argue that technology, rather than being a universal good that empowers the masses, can instead be and has been utilized to give large corporations and governments greater and greater control at the expense of individual consumers and small businesses; therefore we must consider &quot;who is devising the technology and why,&quot; and push for open systems and decentralized technologies.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Small auto repair shops across America are being forced to close as car manufacturers make vehicles increasingly dependent on expensive computerized diagnostic tools, reflecting how corporate-controlled technology often restricts rather than democratizes access to knowledge and repair capabilities.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) The closure of a longstanding car repair shop, attributed to the increasing complexity and proprietary technology of modern cars, highlights a broader economic trend where advancements in technology can undermine small businesses and restrict consumer autonomy, questioning the assumption that technology inherently democratizes and empowers users.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The document argues that technology, including corporate-designed computers and cars, is often designed to exert control over users and small shop owners, rather than promoting autonomy and open systems.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) Independent car repair shops are struggling due to technological advancements in modern vehicles that require costly and specialized equipment, challenging the traditional narrative that technology inherently benefits individuals and society.
#Text=Tools and Tasks
#Text=By Anonymous
#Text=" Andrew s clutch job " by Bob n Renee is licensed under CC BY 2.0
#Text=My town is losing a car repair shop .
#Text=The gas station at the end of Main Street will continue to sell gas , but the garage attached to it is going to close .
#Text=The mechanic , who has been there for twenty - five years , will have to find work elsewhere .
#Text=He had a loyal following ; a friend told me he once opened early on a Sunday to fix her tire .
#Text=The garage is n’t closing for lack of customers .
#Text=Nor is it closing because of taxes , that ritual demon of the political Right .
#Text=A major reason , the owner said , is technology , and the way manufacturers are making cars so complex .
#Text=To fix them requires sophisticated computers that a small shop ca n’t afford .
#Text=“ There is n’t a car from the ’70s or ’80s that we ca n’t work on , ” the owner told our local weekly .
#Text=“ But we ’re not in the position to make the investment in all the electronics and computers .
#Text=To make that transition would be cost prohibitive . ”
#Text=He ’s not the only one .
#Text=Independent repair shops are going out of business all over the country .
#Text=In California , more than half the gas stations had repair shops as recently as ten years ago .
#Text=Now about 15 % of them do .
#Text=Part of that is because oil companies are forcing out independent owners and taking over the retail end themselves .
#Text=( Have you noticed that prices are rising ? )
#Text=But partly too it ’s because the local shops ca n’t repair the new computerized cars .
#Text=This is a trend that bears more scrutiny than it has received .
#Text=It goes to two of the central narratives of our economy — the conventional version at least .
#Text=One is that virtue and hard work prevail , which in this case is not the case .
#Text=Hard work and virtue have succumbed to corporate contrivance .
#Text=You are shocked ?
#Text=The other narrative is the one that casts technology as Savior .
#Text=The word itself has become practically a synonym for “ future . ”
#Text=Computers are portrayed as the ultimate instruments of democracy .
#Text=They will put knowledge — and therefore power — on every desktop .
#Text=They will cause hierarchies and bureaucracies to crumble .
#Text=Every man and woman will be a king .

#Text=“ While the Industrial Revolution herded people into gigantic social institutions — big corporations , big unions , big governments , ” wrote Newt Gingrich in his book To Renew America , “ the Information Revolution is breaking up these giants and leading us back to something that is — strangely enough — much more like de Tocqueville ’s 1830s America . ”
#Text=Brother Newton is a busy man , and maybe he just did n’t have time to consider the complications .
#Text=For one thing , there ’s the matter of agency .
#Text=As David Noble observed in his book Forces of Production , technology is not an impersonal force .
#Text=It does not have an inevitable evolutionary path .
#Text=Technology is a projection of those who make it , including corporate interests and proprietary claims .
#Text=This can lead to a lot of trouble .
#Text=Noble looks in particular at the machine tool industry , and how it evolved to enable top - down management control instead of autonomy on the shop floor .
#Text=The technology could have gone either way ; it was the corporate managers who made the call .
#Text=Computers have followed a similar pattern .
#Text=Potentially they can liberate the desktop , and sometimes do .
#Text=But in practice they often do the opposite .
#Text=Now the boss can monitor your every keystroke .
#Text=At home corporations can plant little spies on your machine .
#Text=The Feds can track your personal e-mail exchanges .
#Text=You think the Department of Homeland Security might have a computer or two ?
#Text=And so with the technology built into cars .
#Text=It would seem possible to design it in a way that made cars simpler and less expensive to repair .
#Text=I do n’t really know , but it does seem reasonable .
#Text=The problem is , would it fit the business plans of the corporations that make the cars ?
#Text=Why would General Motors want to put more capacity and control into the hands of independent garages like the one in my town ?
#Text=Would n’t it want to lock a customer into its own repair and dealer network , much the way computer printer manufacturers try to lock us into their expensive cartridges ?
#Text=That seems to be what ’s happening .
#Text=Car repair used to be a knowledge commons , shared in driveways , urban curbsides , and voc. ed. classes .
#Text=Get yourself some tools and you were ready to go for most routine repairs .
#Text=The machines were open to the eye .
#Text=There was little if any secret and proprietary code .
#Text=Repair manuals could help with the more technical issues , but you ’d probably go to a shop for those anyway . [ ... ]
#Text=I am not suggesting that we all go back to bamboo huts , though a few weeks might not be the worst thing now and then .
#Text=I am just questioning the techno - romantics who think technology by its very nature is enlarging and fulfilling .
#Text=Sometimes it does the opposite , and hollows us out .
#Text=Adam Smith actually had a glimmer of this , regarding the effect of the division of labor upon the workers involved .
#Text=As each task becomes more specialized , Smith noted , it engages less of the person .
#Text=Narrow work leads to human atrophy ; it can make people “ as stupid and ignorant as it is possible for a human creature to become . ”
#Text=( Smith had a brooding cautionary side that is lacking among his acolytes today . )
#Text=What ’s happening now is bigger and more endemic .
#Text=It affects people not just as employees but as “ consumers ” even more ( and consumption is the real work of our “ economy ” to begin with . )
#Text=This is a big topic , obviously , but a lot goes back to who is devising the technology and why .
#Text=Open technologies and open systems are less inclined to the unvirtuous cycle than closed ones are .
#Text=There ’s a built - in social dimension that engages us at more levels , as producers as well as just consumers .
#Text=Open systems evolve to serve the needs of users rather than of those who seek to use the users for their own ends .
#Text=Compare , for example , traditional fairy tales with the kiddy entertainment today that has embedded products such as candy bars and colas .
#Text=When someone finally writes the sequel to The Wealth of Nations , open systems and decentralized technologies will be , I think , a central theme .
#Text=Perhaps a working title could be From the Wealth of Nations to the Well - Being of the People Involved .
